channel.title: tir
channel.description: "Today I Read:" a collection of the little things you read each day. Cherish them!

item.title: Seek, but shall ye find?
item.description: Submarines are getting quieter, so underwater drones should track them constantly. More on how carriers are out.

item.title: Image Completion with Deep Learning in TensorFlow
item.description: Very good breakdown of how CNNs can recreate images; super well-explained.

item.title: Generating fantasy maps
item.description: A quick guide to generating realistic fictional maps.

item.title: Generating naming languages
item.description: How-to for generating a simple language that sounds consistent

item.title: Spiritual Emergency
item.description: Short clinical trials are bad at gauging long-term impacts of drugs on the brain.

item.title: Datagasm
item.description: Porn is turning to data to target niche fetishes, which is a necessaryy response to piracy. Data is upmarket.

item.title: Mimesis, Violence, and Facebook: Peter Thiel's French Connection
item.description: Social networks are successful because of mimetic (meme) desire; they shape mimetic violence and, power (says Giraud via Thiel)

item.title: Emptiness
item.description: Do I have Narcissistic Personality Disorder (NPD)?

item.title: How I wrote and published my novel using only open source tools
item.description: Markdown, Pandoc, and CreateSpace.

item.title: What I Assume Honore de Balzac Thought After Drinking Each of His Fifty Daily Cups of Coffee
item.description: Hilarious stream of consciousness.

item.title: Build-a-brain
item.description: Attention is the essence of consciousness that builds a self/other divide, and computers could theoretically learn it

item.title: Typography is impossible
item.description: A lot of problems come from putting text in boxes because text flows.

item.title: Pete Wells Has His Knives Out
item.description: A really intense and wonderful profile of the NYT food critic.

item.title: Why are the Microsoft Office file formats so complicated?
item.description: Interesting look at how early dev priorities don't jive with extension development

item.title: A journey along Japan's oldest pilgrimage route
item.description: Reminds me of the Kumano Kodo; interesting discussion of post-fascist spirituality

item.title: A Pixel Artist Renounces Pixel Art
item.description: When consumers don't understand piel art as a deliberate choice it doesn't achieve its intended effect.

item.title: Making Sense of Modern Pornography
item.description: Democratized production is killing porn as an industry

item.title: The Art of War: Deleuze, Guattari, Debord and the Israeli Defence Force
item.description: The IDF turns high theory (DNG) into a smart weapon, walks through walls..

item.title: Debunking the Cul-de-Sac
item.description: The graph theory of suburbs makes them more dangerous for traffic.

item.title: The Free-Time Paradox in America
item.description: Examines why the rich don't work less.

item.title: Donald Trump Jr. Is His Father's Id
item.description: As the Trump campaign gets careful, Jr. goes more alt right.

item.title: Why the silencing of KrebsOnSecurity opens a troubling chapter for the 'Net
item.description: Unsecured IOT become a huge DDoS engine, shutting down security writers.

item.title: When a Chinese PhD Student Meets a German Supervisor
item.description: Describes approaches to tackling cultural differences; the difficulties are pretty incredible.

item.title: The real problem
item.description: Director of the Sackler Center: the real problem is to piecewise link conscious phenomena to physical phenomena, which indicates that perception corrects prediction.

item.title: My Journey to the Center of the Alt-Right
item.description: A big investigative project examining how white supremacy is going mainstream, ack!

item.title: Reprogramming the Navy
item.description: Large, complex systems like the Zumwalt warrant scriptability for different scenarios

item.title: Disqualified
item.description: The democratic party alienates via a political rhetoric of competence.

item.title: Four Poems
item.description: Awesome poems about Russian politics and the relationship between poet and proletariat.

item.title: The Last Unknown Man
item.description: Tracking down an identity for an extreme amnesiac over ten years. Interesting re. biopolitical subjects.

item.title: Night's Nirvana
item.description: Investigating Norwegian Black Metal as a series of misreadings

item.title: Safety over sanity
item.description: A trans friend of mine woponders the interaction bof personal identity, family, and history.

item.title: How to Hide $400 Million
item.description: It takes a divorce proceeding to crack open the world of offshore finance

item.title: The Perfect Weapon: How Russian Cyberpower Invaded the U.S.
item.description: NYT investigation of DNC server hacks. But please stop saying 'cyber'...

item.title: The Obama Speeches
item.description: Good Obama speeches focus on a moment of transcendence of division, like clockwork

item.title: The Moral Economy of Tech
item.description: Tech exceptionalism is constructing a surveillance dystopia

item.title: Superintelligence: The Idea That Eats Smart People
item.description: AI obsession makes tech people worse for the world.

item.title: Drugs du jour
item.description: Drugs like modafinil allow people to tie their happiness to their producttivity

item.title: Who is Anna-Senpai, the Mirai Worm Author?
item.description: Mirai was born out of a Minecraft blackmail underworld.

item.title: In the Booth
item.description: Trump's policies constitute a paradigmatic shift from legality towards nationality.

item.title: Lessons for the No-Budget Feature
item.description: Maybe this will come in handy!

item.title: Why Hollywood As We Know It is Already Over
item.description: Hollywood is being outperformed on all fronts by tech; an upmarket collapse is imminent

item.title: Whitey on Mars
item.description: SpaceX is maybe an isolated drive for perfect isolation from everyday problems

item.title: Executive Power Run Amok
item.description: Yoo thinks the Trump administration is overreaching.

item.title: Fire, hatred and speed!
item.description: Alt-right inherits lots from fascist Italian Futurism; technoutopianism and transhumanism might, too.

item.title: Berlin Living Rooms
item.description: A loving description of the flexibility of German living spaces; designed for potential

item.title: While the Iron Is Hot
item.description: A pretty compelling argument in favor of the Women's Strike (March 8).

item.title: America's opioid epidemic is worsening
item.description: Opioid deaths (prescription, heroin, synthetic) are waup 600 percent since e 2000

item.title: The power thinker
item.description: A good explanation of Foucault's continued significance.

item.title: As Goes the Media, So Goes Scholarly Publishing
item.description: Open access movements apply tectonic pressure to academic publishing.

item.title: Can't Disrupt This
item.description: There's lots of support for open access, but disrupting academic publishing starts with a niche underserved area.

item.title: Five Deaths at Dammasch Hospital: a Question of Responsibility
item.description: Tragic postmortems for five patients at a mental health facility in Oregon.

item.title: How Paul Ryan played Donald Trump
item.description: Ryan got Trump to fight for the AHCA, which ended up tanking his credibility. Very Frank Underwood.

item.title: Evolution Strategies as a Scalable Alternative to Reinforcement Learning
item.description: Evolution strategies can outperform reinforcement learning in training: no backprop and they're parallelizable.

item.title: Biopower in Space: Technology, Reproduction, and the Alien Agenda
item.description: Alien abduction stories could have utility for resistance against biopolitics

item.title: Your Patek Philippe Caliber 89 Now Needs A Service
item.description: It's super complicated to mechanically calculate the date of Easter.

item.title: On Campuses Far From China, Still Under Beijing's Watchful Eye
item.description: Rumor has it the Chinese government works with student orgs.

item.title: Betting the Spread on Inexorables
item.description: Unfocused exploration biased towards value is a better MO for work than klong-term planning.

item.title: 3 Approaches to Improving Happiness
item.description: Environment, emotions, and meta-emotional evaluations of emotions. Simple breakdown, but easy to grok.

item.title: What made Bell Labs special?
item.description: Competition is great for incremental innovation, but its absence at Bell led to more dramatic inventions.

item.title: My Family's Slave
item.description: Immigration and modern slavery.

item.title: The Conservative Mind Has Become Diseased
item.description: Suffering has been politically commodified.

item.title: A Very High Degree of Certainty in Future Military Operations
item.description: A largely shoddy article, but fascinating breakdown of what sets McMaster apart.

item.title: A Student's Guide to UC Berkeley's Startup Ecosystem
item.description: An aight overview.

item.title: Frankenstacks and Rhizomes
item.description: The metaphor is a little mangled, but tech org (software, peopleware) is increasingly rhizomatic; Burglar's Guides are the only guides.

item.title: Ghost in the Cloud
item.description: Transhumanism's heavy overlap with christian eschatology.

item.title: Monstrous, Duplicated, Potent: On Donna Haraway
item.description: A good overview of the evolution of Haraway's cyborg feminism.

item.title: The Poverty of Entrepreneurship: The Silicon Valley Theory of History
item.description: This article's mannerisms locate it in reactionary marxist neo-luddism, but it convincingly gives my criticism of mental models in other terms: history is reduced to comforting analogies for the present.

item.title: Why So Many Top Hackers Hail from Russia
item.description: Russia's information security superiority is a product of its primary and secondary informatics education.

item.title: My Father, in Four Visits Over Thirty Years
item.description: The stepwise change in her relationship with her Iranian father

item.title: A Letter To My Mother That She Will Never Read
item.description: Vuong's letter to his illiterate mother about the aftershocks of the Vietnam War in his childhood.

item.title: The Rise of the Thought Leader
item.description: Thought leadership is frequently a shallow appeal to markets.

item.title: How the Left Lost Its Mind
item.description: Conspiracism is rising on the left, just as it did on the right; it's just not as mainstream yet.

item.title: Fear of radiation is more dangerous than radiation itself
item.description: The mental health impacts of nuclear preparedness harms more people than radiation-related illness.

item.title: Semicolon-shaped People
item.description: I'm not as all-in-hyped as Rao, but learning via difference and unstructtured curiosity is cool.

item.title: The Lawyer, the Addict
item.description: Lawyers have elevated rates of drug use. Professional stress and culture contribute to mental health issues.

item.title: Trello CEO Offers Advice on Working Remote
item.description: Assign folks to take point on meaningful social events: coffee, board games...

item.title: Eagles Don't Flock, Elephants Don't Dance
item.description: Kairos: R2R 1.0 to "get eagles to flock." Reminds me of Bayes' Impact problems as well.

item.title: Beat the Clock
item.description: Notes on the struggles of women international athletes and of aging out oof a competition/identity. Makes me think of debate.

item.title: The Rise and Fall of the "Freest Little City in Texas"
item.description: A Texan "liberty city" fails miserably

item.title: Remote Diagnoses
item.description: Espousing irrational actor theories makes belligerence intuitively attractive; maybe mis-applied with North Korea.

item.title: Fairouz in Exile
item.description: Fairouz as the soundtrack for Syrian diaspora.

item.title: Fast inverse square root
item.description: A super counterintuitive approximation algorithm.

item.title: A Need to Walk
item.description: A very sentimental but reference-heavy post on the magic of walking places.

item.title: Can A Third-Party Ticket Win In 2020?
item.description: Less likely than a celebrity ticket, and conditional on a weak dem ticket and a splintered right.

item.title: How Not To Sort By Average Rating
item.description: Sorting by ratings is best done with Wilson score/Bernoulli parameter.

item.title: Keeping Kids Frenetically Entertained is Ruining our Museums
item.description: Common places for study have tended towards entertainment instead.

item.title: Movies, patriotism, and cultural amnesia
item.description: Pop culture since 9/11 has frequently had to address it, with various results.

item.title: The Premium Mediocre Life of Maya Millennial
item.description: There's a 'premium mediocre' class of products for class-aspirational millenials (think Sweetgreen)

item.title: The Outside Man
item.description: Snowden's leaks are unlike effective whistleblowing, which is much more strategic and evenhanded. E.g. Ellsberg.

item.title: Is Hillary Clinton Right About Why She Lost?
item.description: For the most part, yes.

item.title: Explaining White Polarization in the 2016 Vote for President
item.description: Racism and sexism indices suggest an better explanation for the college education voting gap among whites than economic satisfaction.

item.title: How the Elderly Lose their Rights
item.description: It'spretty shocking how permanent legal disenfranchisement is; this whole article was terrifying.

item.title: The Supreme Court Is Allergic To Math
item.description: High courts do poorly with metrics and measures, e.g. in Gill v. Whitford. Or are they masking biases?

item.title: Silicon Valley: a Reality Check
item.description: SV pessimism stems from undercoverage of the best work (early science, nonprofit endeavors), which doesn't trade off with Juicero.

item.title: When we only hire the best means we only hire the trendiest
item.description: Tech companies hire for trendy traits rather than raw ability, which isn't productive.

item.title: America is facing an epistemic crisis
item.description: Paranoid epistemologies might impede Mueller's investigation; is "real news" characterized by self-correction?

item.title: Why the idea that the world is in terminal decline is so dangerous
item.description: Assange champions a declinism that pairs with palingenetic fascism. Declinism is a misunderstanding of, barrier to change.

item.title: Not Every Kid-Bond Matures
item.description: I disagree plenty, but an interesting observation of a uniquely neoliberal mimillennial subjectivity.

item.title: Something is wrong on the internet
item.description: A very postmodern and very disconcerting trends in algorithmically-generated YouTube videos.

item.title: The secret backstory of how Obama let Hezbollah off the hook
item.description: The Obama administration deprioritized Hezbollah-cartel ties to focus on the Iran Deal. Complete with amazing animated illustrations.

item.title: Artwork Personalization at Netflix
item.description: Netflix uses contextual bandits to select promo artwork for each user.

item.title: Google Maps's Moat
item.description: Google Maps is way ahead of competitors on building shapes, areas of interest. Ends up being data-defensible.

item.title: Conspicuous consumption is over. It's all about intangibles now.
item.description: Inconspicuous consumption is premium mediocre for the upper class; counterpart to Venkatesh Rao's bit on premium mediocrity.

item.title: How the Efficiency Gap Works
item.description: Brief on the math behind the Efficiency Gap from Gill v. Whitford.

item.title: Gerrymandering Is On Trial
item.description: Breakdown of Gill v. Whitford into the central questions; context for Vieth v. Jubelirer

item.title: Vieth v. Jubelirer
item.description: Kennedy looks for a clear and consistent standard for court intervention in redistricting (2004)

item.title: Collision Course: Why This Type of Road Junction Will Keep Killing Cyclists
item.description: Constant-speed intersection approaches can lead to tracking blind spots.

item.title: Deep Inside: A Study of 10,000 Porn Stars and Their Careers
item.description: 2013 analysis of porn star demographics and career statistics. Surprisng: similar racial makeup to the United States on the whole.

item.title: In the Eating Disorder Unit
item.description: A pretty shocking experience with the NHS's eating disorder support services.

item.title: The Fall of Travis Kalanick Was a Lot Weirder and Darker Than You Thought
item.description: A chronicle of Uber's constant turmoil in the past year.

item.title: Oscars 2018: Here Are Our Early Predictions
item.description: Oscar predictions generated by weighting the prescience of other awards.

item.title: How Schopenhauer's thought can illuminate a midlife crisis
item.description: Suggests crisis is connected to repetition in activities that have an endpoint, rather than a focus on process.

item.title: How a malicious seed generation website stole $4 million
item.description: By obfuscating javascript in image data, reading certain bytes in, and evaluating them; using a different image in production.

item.title: Fix the F.B.I. Don't Politicize It.
item.description: The FBI has become increasingly political, but current reforms mark a trend towards further politicization.

item.title: Until They Inevitably Find and Kill Each Other
item.description: n+1 reviews video games, with typical n+1 bleakness.

item.title: Why Paper Jams Persist
item.description: Paper jams are inevitable with unpredictable inputs (paper) to finely-tuned systems (printers).

item.title: Few things are as dangerous as economists with physics envy
item.description: Fundamnetal laws of economics are fuzzy at best, and the search for fundamental laws can be misleading.

item.title: Sandboxed Mac apps can record your screen
item.description: Part of the Mac OS screenshot API is unrestricted.

item.title: Worst Roommate Ever
item.description: Story about a serial bad roommate.

item.title: Phantasmic Phoenicia
item.description: A distinct phoenecian national identity was invented via nationalism in the 19th, 20th centuries.

item.title: Cryptographic Right Answers
item.description: Rundown of a bunch of information security best practices.

item.title: "The Clock is Ticking": Inside the Worst U.S. Maritime Disaster in Decades
item.description: Polished postmortem for the SS El Faro; big issue was preference in attractive data streams over inconvenient but accurate ones.

item.title: Richard Turley creates a characteristically hilarious cover inspired by Jonathan Ive
item.description: Just hilarious art writing.

item.title: Day of Memory
item.description: Reflection on the investigation of Soviet mass-executions.

item.title: Is Comey Helping or Hurting #TheResistance?
item.description: Comey's book and press tour erode the reputation for impersonal precision that made his testimony so strong.

item.title: Artificial Intelligence — The Revolution Hasn’t Happened Yet
item.description: "AI," inasmuch as it suggests the immitation of human intelligence, is a often a misnomer. Also, AI-style research is more interesting for solving kinds of problems human intelligence can't.

item.title: Chiropractors are Bullshit
item.description: Chiropractic is largely based on pseudoscience, and its spread outside of pain management can be seriously dangerous.

item.title: We're the Good Guys, Right?
item.description: Argues Marvel's latest round of superhero revivalism is bleakly nationalistic.

item.title: How Anna Delvey Tricked New York
item.description: Kind of a slow heist: a faux-socialite finances a debauch lifestyle with credit and art-world fraud. Super New York.

item.title: Ex Machina and the Art of Character Identification
item.description: Ex Machina's excellence lies in its moral neutrality; that the final action is morally opaque leaves room for interpretation on gender and AI.

item.title: In Search of the Last Great Video Store
item.description: The disappearance of video stores, coupled with online streaming's focus on OC, means movie availability is sharply and suddenly decreasing (esp. for the unremarkable).

item.title: The Church of Food: On Anthony Bourdain, 1956–2018
item.description: Bourdain did food writing without condescension, and wavered between political optimism and a bleak realism. Favorite part: discussion of his Beirut trip, p in 2006.

item.title: He Was a Crook
item.description: Obituary of Richard Nixon. "Evil in a way that only those who believe in the physical reality of the Devil can understand it."

item.title: The Globalist
item.description: Discussion of George Soros's political and philosophical mission. Pretty compelling, if par for the n+1 course on capital.

item.title: The Death of a Once Great City
item.description: New York hyperluxury developments are frequently left empty. TDisplacement produces a kind of cultural void.

item.title: An Extraordinarily Expensive Way to Fight ISIS
item.description: Most interestingly, it suggests that drone warfare is more personal than crewed high-altitude bombing with smart bombs.

item.title: Little St. Don
item.description: Shouts & Murmers highlight: trump as a petit saint.

item.title: Increasingly Tenuous Strategic Stability
item.description: Nuclear outcomes in intermediate use––not just in huge retaliation––is are important in decisionmaking. They are in flux.

item.title: Piss Trump
item.description: Satire: Hannity fantasizes about Moscow tapes.

item.title: The Perils of Small-Group Thought
item.description: Optimism plagues the small group and individual decisions that would precipitate nuclear war.

item.title: Death in the Nuclear Age
item.description: "We continue to think and act as though the possibility of nuclear death portended only a quantitative extension of the mass destruction of the past and not a qualitative transformation of the meaning of our existence."

item.title: Future Cyberwar
item.description: A hypothetical unconventional attack, via the credit scores and preputations of members of the military.

item.title: George Soros on George Soros
item.description: A response to the noteworthy n+1 review of Soros's philosophy.

item.title: The New Reading Environment
item.description: Online reader interaction, reaction, and regurgitating dramatically change writing in the first place.

item.title: I have impeached myself
item.description: Richard Nixon's retrospective on his presidency, and especially its end.

item.title: Orthodoxxed!
item.description: Criticism of Sokal-style academic hoaxes. I don't agree with it entirely, but it points out correctly that the role of acadmic publications is more complicated than determining value.

item.title: Decision Engines
item.description: Probably the form of the first self-driving car movie.

item.title: Private BitTorrent trackers are markets
item.description: Light summary of a late paper. Incentives can be adjusted to increase availability of old files.

item.title: Violence and the Sacred: College as an incubator of Girardian terror
item.description: Observes violence for differentiation. I disagree entirely with the subtext about the value of college, but the analysis was enjoyable.

item.title: #GorsuchDictionaries: Into the lexicographic weeds
item.description: Scalia really didn't like Webster's 3.

item.title: Remember Me on This Computer
item.description: Angsty: argues the internet is gutting film criticism. Good enough that I bought Hamrah's book.
